newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bank shares plunge on rate jitters.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bank shares plunge on rate jitters.

text.p: Shares of the six major Canadian banks tumbled after the U.S. government reported higher than expected producer prices for March.
The bank index on the Toronto Stock Exchange tumbled 2.63 percent or down more than 11 points after the core producer price index rose 0.4 percent, compared to market expectations of 0.1 percent.

Shares of the Bank of Nova Scotia, Bank of Montreal and the Royal Bank of Canada fell furthest by midday, both down 1.45 to 48.70 a share for Scotia, 51.15 a share for Royal and 45.75 a share for Montreal.

Traders said the economic data increased market speculation that inflationary pressure in the U.S. will force the U.S. Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the second time since 1995 when the Federal Open Market Committee meets in May. They said such a rise will increase pressure on the Bank of Canada to raise its domestic rates.
"Interest rates are moving higher and the banks always get knocked down," one trader said.
Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce shares fell 1.05 to 29.85 a share, Toronto-Dominion Bank shares fell 0.80 to 35.40 a share and National Bank of Canada shares were down 0.35 to 13.75 a share.
